member.name: T:SimpleBase.Base16
member.summary: Base16 encoding/decoding.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base16.#ctor(SimpleBase.Base16Alphabet)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:SimpleBase.Base16.UpperCase
member.summary: Gets upper case Base16 encoder. Decoding is case-insensitive.

member.summary: Gets lower case Base16 encoder. Decoding is case-insensitive.

member.summary: Gets the alphabet used by the encoder.

member.summary: Decode Upper/Lowercase Base16 text into bytes.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base16.DecodeAsync(System.IO.TextReader,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Decode Base16 text through streams for generic use. Stream based variant tries to consume as little memory as possible, and relies of .NET's own underlying buffering mechanisms, contrary to their buffer-based versions.
member.param: Stream that the encoded bytes would be read from.
Stream where decoded bytes will be written to.
member.returns: Task that represents the async operation.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base16.Decode(System.IO.TextReader,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Decode Base16 text through streams for generic use. Stream based variant tries to consume as little memory as possible, and relies of .NET's own underlying buffering mechanisms, contrary to their buffer-based versions.
member.param: Stream that the encoded bytes would be read from.
Stream where decoded bytes will be written to.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base16.Encode(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.TextWriter)
member.summary: Encodes stream of bytes into a Base16 text.
member.param: Stream that provides bytes to be encoded.
Stream that the encoded text is written to.

member.summary: Encodes stream of bytes into a Base16 text.
member.param: Stream that provides bytes to be encoded.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the alphabet uses one of shortcut characters for all spaces or all zeros.

member.name: T:SimpleBase.Base85Ipv6
member.summary: Base85 implementation with additional IPv6 coding functions.
member.remarks: RFC 1924 sucks, arguably because it's a very early proposal in the history of IPv6: - It contains special chars: It's prone to be confused with other syntactical elements. It can even cause security issues due to poor escaping, let alone UX problems. - Length gains are usually marginal: IPv6 uses zero elimination to reduce the address representation. - Slow. The algorithm is division based, instead of faster bitwise operations. So, that's why I only included a proof of concept implementation instead of working on optimizing it. RFC 1924 should die, and this code should only be used to support some obscure standard or code somewhere.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base85Ipv6.#ctor(SimpleBase.Base85Alphabet)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base85Ipv6.EncodeIpv6(System.Net.IPAddress)
member.summary: Encode IPv6 address into RFC 1924 Base85 text.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.Base85Ipv6.DecodeIpv6(System.String)
member.summary: Decode an RFC 1924 encoded text into an IPv6 address.

member.name: T:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet
member.summary: A single encoding algorithm can support many different alphabets. EncodingAlphabet consists of a basis for implementing different alphabets for different encodings. It's suitable if you want to implement your own encoding based on the existing base classes.

member.name: F:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.maxLength
member.summary: Specifies the highest possible char value in an encoding alphabet Any char above with would raise an exception.

member.name: F:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.reverseLookupTable
member.summary: Holds a mapping from character to an actual byte value The values are held as "value + 1" so a zero would denote "not set" and would cause an exception.
member.remarks: byte[] has no discernible perf impact and saves memory.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.Length
member.summary: Gets the length of the alphabet.

member.name: P:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.Value
member.summary: Gets the characters of the alphabet.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.InvalidCharacter(System.Char)
member.summary: Generates a standard invalid character exception for alphabets.
member.remarks: The reason this is not a throwing method itself is that the compiler has no way of knowing whether the execution will end after the method call and can incorrectly assume reachable code.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.ToString
member.summary: Get the string representation of the alphabet.
member.returns: The characters of the encoding alphabet.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.CodingAlphabet.Map(System.Char,System.Int32)
member.summary: Map a character to a value.

member.name: T:SimpleBase.INonAllocatingBaseCoder
member.summary: Efficient encoding functionality using pre-allocated memory buffers by the callers.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.INonAllocatingBaseCoder.TryEncode(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte},System.Span{System.Char},System.Int32@)
member.summary: Encode a buffer into a base-encoded representation using pre-allocated buffers.
member.param: Actual number of characters written to the output.
member.returns: Whether encoding was successful or not. If false, will be zero and the content of will be undefined.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.INonAllocatingBaseCoder.TryDecode(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char},System.Span{System.Byte},System.Int32@)
member.summary: Decode an encoded character buffer into a pre-allocated output buffer.
member.param: Actual number of bytes written to the output.
member.returns: Whether decoding was successful. If false, the value of will be zero and the content of will be undefined.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.INonAllocatingBaseCoder.GetSafeByteCountForDecoding(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char})
member.summary: Gets a safe estimation about how many bytes decoding will take without performing the actual decoding operation. The estimation can be slightly larger than the actual output size.
member.returns: Number of estimated bytes, or zero if the input length is invalid.

member.name: M:SimpleBase.INonAllocatingBaseCoder.GetSafeCharCountForEncoding(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte})
member.summary: Gets a safe estimation about how many characters encoding a buffer will take without performing the actual encoding operation. The estimation can be slightly larger than the actual output size.
member.returns: Number of estimated characters, or zero if the input length is invalid.
